urn:contentItem:605K-PWJ1-JD34-V3YB-00000-00End of Victorian firewood collection season2020-06-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisEnd of Victorian firewood collection season

The autumn 2020 Firewood Collection Season will close across the state at midnight Tuesday, June 30.

Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) Chief Fire Officer, Chris Hardman said, "From Wednesday, July 1 it is illegal to collect firewood and there are serious penalties for failing to follow firewood collection rules.

"Under Victorian legislation, firewood can only be collected during the firewood collection seasons from March 1 to June 30, 2020 (autumn season) and September 1 to November 30, 2020 (spring season)."

"Limits are in place to prevent households stockpiling large volumes of firewood from public land and denying others a supply."

Any information the community may have about the illegal removal of firewood for sale can be reported to DELWP on 136 186.

Concession card holders who rely only on buying firewood for home heating may be eligible for the non-mains energy concession.

More information is available on the Department of Health and Human Services website: https://services.dhhs.vic.gov.au/non-mains-energy-concession

Victorians on low incomes (both concession card and non-concession card holders) who rely on buying firewood and have experienced unexpected financial hardship may also be eligible to apply for the non-mains utility relief grant of up to $650 to help with firewood costs.

A person may apply for the grant if they have an amount owing for a previous firewood purchase, or if they will not be able to afford their next firewood purchase.

Information on eligibility for the Non-Mains Utility Relief Grant Scheme can be found at: https://services.dhhs.vic.gov.au/utility-relief-grant-scheme-non-mains

For more information on available financial assistance, community members should phone the Concessions information line on 1800 658 521.

FFMVic supports domestic firewood provision through the creation of firewood collection areas on public land and a list of these areas can be found at www.ffm.vic.gov.au/firewood

During the designated collection periods an individual can collect a maximum of two cubic metres of firewood in a day and may collect up to 16 cubic metres per household per financial year.

If you are collecting firewood before the season ends, be considerate, use common sense, follow physical distancing requirements and stay safe.

urn:contentItem:61Y0-2MC1-F03R-N3VH-00000-00World's Tiniest Reptile Found In Madagascar2021-02-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisWorld's Tiniest Reptile Found In Madagascar

Feb 06, 2021( International Business Times Australia: http://www.ibtimes.com.au/ Delivered by Newstex) Scientists have identified Earth's smallest known reptile, warning at the same time that sustained destruction of forests in northern Madagascar threatens its survival. Tiny enough to perch comfortably on a fingertip, the ultra-compact chameleon -- dubbed Brookesia nana -- has the same proportions and world-weary expression as its larger cousins around the world. "We discovered it in the mountains of northern of Madagascar," Frank Glaw, curator of herpetology at the Bavarian State Collection of Zoology, told AFP in an interview.

A joint expedition in 2012 of German and Malagasy scientists did not know whether the two specimens collected -- one female and one male -- were adults until much later, he explained. "We found out that the female had eggs in her body, and that the male had large genitals, so it was clear that they were adults." Exceptionally large genitals, it turned out, accounting for nearly 20 percent of its body size, Glaw and colleagues reported in the journal Scientific Reports. Tiny enough to perch comfortably on a fingertip, the ultra-compact chameleon -- dubbed Brookesia nana -- has the same proportions and world-weary expression as its larger cousins around the world Zoologische Staatssammlung Munchen / Frank GLAW The male's body -- about the size of a peanut -- was 13.5 millimetres long (half an inch), with the tail adding another nine millimetres. By contrast, the female measured 29 mm from its nose to the tip of its tail. The pair remain the only specimens of the species ever found. Islands connected long ago to neighbouring continents are known for miniaturised versions of animals that crossed ephemeral land bridges, a phenomenon known as "island dwarfism". "There are numerous extremely miniaturised vertebrates in Madagascar, including the smallest primates and some of the smallest frogs in the world," said co-author Andolalao Rakotoarison of the University of Antananarivo in Madagascar. But the "island effect" does not apply to B. nana, which lives exclusively in mountainous regions some 1,300 metres (4,200 feet) above sea level, the researchers concluded. Since the mid-20th century, Madagascar has lost about 45 percent of its forest cover Zoologische Staatssammlung Munchen / Frank GLAW "We have no good explanation as to why this species is so small," said Glaw. What scientists do know is that the diminutive reptiles are likely teetering on the edge of extinction, even if the International Union for the Conservation for Nature (IUCN) -- keepers of the Red List of threatened species -- has yet to do an assessment. "Habitat destruction is the biggest threat to the amphibians and reptiles of Madagascar," said Glaw. "Maybe in the future it will be climate change, but for now it is deforestation." Since the mid-20th century, Madagascar has lost about 45 percent of its forest cover. B. nana and another mini-chameleon discovered by Glaw and his colleagues on a small island off the coast of Madagascar are especially vulnerable because their range is so small. Brookesia micra lives on less than two square kilometres," Glaw explained. "One big catastrophic event -- a forest fire -- and the population might be lost very quickly." Madagascar in a global "biodiversity hotspot", accounting for five percent of the world's unique plant and animal species. The island nation has one of the highest rates of poverty in the world, and lacks resources for conservation and natural resource management.

urn:contentItem:6052-GK91-F0JP-W0W4-00000-00Boost for predicting bushfires2020-06-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 19Boost for predicting bushfiresANTHONY DOWSLEY

NEW systems to predict the risk of large-scale bushfires are being developed by Victoria's bushfire authorities.

The Royal Commission into National Natural Disaster -Arrangements resumed its public hearings yesterday with a focus on hazard reduction.

Prescribed burning ahead of the fire season can mitigate but not eliminate the risks of bushfires, the royal commission was told. Drier, longer seasons, as an impact of climate change, were highlighted.

Victoria's bushfire simulators analyse 11,500 planned fires lit across the state to model how fires behave as they progress through landscape.

The modelling provides a residual risk score based on the potential loss of houses.

Last year in Gippsland, the bushfire risk had risen to 72 per cent, having increased almost 30 per cent in four years.

Chief Fire Officer Chris Hardman of Forest Fire Management Victoria said a "fire risk matrix" was being developed to better predict the risk of large-scale fires.

But Mr Hardman said Victoria had been prepared for "extreme fire risks" heading into the previous fire season.

"We were very well prepared for the extent and severity of the fires," he said. Earlier, senior counsel assisting the commission Dominique Hogan-Doran SC said there was much debate about the effectiveness and benefits of different vegetation-related hazard reduction activities.

"It appears common ground that prescribed burns can mitigate but not eliminate the risks associated with bushfire," she said. "Objective of these burns is to support other risk management measures, including fire suppression, urban planning and building regulations." Ms Hogan-Doran said a theme from public submissions was the uncertainty and complexity in navigating the -bureaucracy when individuals and businesses want to take personal responsibility for managing hazard risk.

The devastating 2019-20 bushfires sparked renewed debate about the effectiveness of prescribed or planned burning.

States and territories use different fuel load management strategies, partly because they have different natural environments, while authorities have pointed to a shrinking window of opportunity for fuel reduction burning as bushfire seasons have lengthened.

The commission also heard that Australia had almost as many firestorms - bushfires so intense they create their own weather systems - in the "Black Summer" season than in the previous three decades.

Firestorms, or pyrocumulonimbus events, were previously considered to be "bushfire oddities", expert David Bowman said. anthony.dowsley@news.com.au

urn:contentItem:62DX-N1Y1-JD34-V0PV-00000-00GALLERY| Memorial service to honour our fallen heroes2021-04-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisGALLERY| Memorial service to honour our fallen heroesElisabeth Champion

Volunteer firefighters who were killed in the line of duty have been remembered in a moving memorial service on Saturday.

Dozens of people from the Country Fire Service, South Australia Police, SA Ambulance Service, local councils and the community braved the wind and the rain at the memorial in Naracoorte to pay their respects to the hard working volunteers who lost their lives.

Vice chairperson of the SA Volunteers Firefighters Museum Allan Hall welcomed everyone to the service and acknowledged members who were unable to join the service.

"It is good to see the people we have here today. We've got a number of members who are not well enough to travel anymore, and it is quite emotional to not have them here.

"We also have to acknowledge some members that we have lost over the past two years.

"Everything that has happened since we were last here, particularly the last 12 months with this lovely pandemic, still doesn't take away from the significance of what we are here for today - acknowledging the number of CFS Volunteers that have lost their lives in the battle against fire and the eight foresty men.

"We all go out, we all do the job but these are people who, through no fault of their own, didn't come home."

Member for Barker Tony Pasin said the CFS was made up of 'selfless individuals" and passed on a message of thanks from Prime Minister Scott Morrison.

"We don't have to think back for either in time or geography from this place - we only need to look back in time to the recent Blackford/Avenue Range fire, which burnt 14,000 hectares with significant stock losses that impacted 75 landholders and homes and infrastructures destroyed," he said.

"Despite those losses, I know members of the community are grateful for the help that came their way on the fire day.

"Without the assistance of the numerous organisations - the formal units, farm fire units, then events that befell the people of Avenue Range, Blackford and Lucindale would have been much worse.

"To every paid and unpaid professional that fought that fire, and indeed given our remembrance today every other bushfire we have faced, I have a single message and this is a message the Prime Minister has asked me to deliver to you - it's two words and it's thank you."

Member for Mackillop Nick McBride and CFS Chief Offiecr Mark Jones also spoke and paid their respects.

Talented musician Bev Branson performed two moving numbers, and Piper Rosemary Gerhardy played the bagpipes.

Pastor Andrew Everson conducted the service and Padthaway CFS cadets assisted with the lowering of the flags.

Those in attendance came forward and laid wreaths at the memorial following a minutes silence.

IN MEMORY OF South Australian EFS and CFS volunteers

Barry McLoughlin, Athelstone Brigade, 1979 Andrew Lemke, Lucindale Brigade, 1983 Peter Matthies, Summertown Brigade, 1983 Brian Nosworthy, Callendale Brigade, 1983 Dean Dennis, Yeelanna Brigade, 1985 Brian Fox, Lobethal Brigade, 1986 Peter Stacy, Burnside Brigade, 1990 Howard Kruse, Waterloo Brigade 1990 Robert Jones, Yahl Brigade, 1991 Peter Aird, Moorook, 1993 Leslie Peek, Strathalbyn Brigade, 1994 Trent Murnane, Cummins Brigade, 2005 Neil Richardson, Ungarra Brigade, 2005 Andrew Harrison, Mt Templeton Brigade, 2014 Brian Johnston, Millicent Brigade, 2014 And Woods and Forests employees killed in the Wandilo Forest Fire, April 5, 1958

Remo Quaggiato, 25 Bernardus Hendrikus Damhuis, 16 Charles Theodore Dolling, 45 Victor Lawrence Fensom, 45 Bertram Wilson, 51 Maurice Henry Treloar, 27 Walter Pascoe Pearce, 46 Francis Burdett, 49

urn:contentItem:6189-BTN1-JD34-V3S8-00000-00Patrols to crackdown on illegal campfires in Grampians region2020-11-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisPatrols to crackdown on illegal campfires in Grampians regionJuanita Greville

If you are heading to the Grampians to camp this weekend, make sure you know your campfire safety rules.

Checks in the region will target illegal campfires as the Conservation Regulator steps up patrols.

About 10 per cent of all bushfires are caused by campfire negligence.

Popular camping and recreation areas from Lake Burrumbeet through to the Rocklands reservoir area, on the western side of the Grampians range, will be part of the crackdown by Conservation Regulator officers and Forest Fire Management Victoria.

Officers will look for unsafe campfires to prevent bushfires being started by negligence and penalise people found in breach of campfire safety rules.

State government announces free kinder in 2021

"All too often we see the consequences of people ignoring campfire safety rules, with approximately ten per cent of all bushfires caused by campfire negligence, " Brian Hamer, Manager Regulatory Operations, said.

"It is a serious offence to leave a fire unattended, even for a short while, as most campfires escape when left unattended."

"If you light a campfire, you are legally responsible for ensuring it is safe, does not escape and is

Visitors will also be reminded about campfire safety and encouraged to report suspicious or illegal activities, including unattended campfires, to 136 186.

The following campfire safety rules are always in force on public land:

1. In state forests, use a purpose-built fireplace if provided, otherwise use a trench at least 30 cm deep.

2. In national and state parks, campfires may only be lit in purpose-built fireplaces provided.

3. Branches and logs on campfires must be less than one metre long.

4. Never leave a campfire alight or unattended.

5. Fully extinguish your campfire with water, not soil.

6. All campfires are banned on Total Fire Ban days.

OTHER NEWS: SHHS ... VCE exams are now underway

The maximum penalty for lighting a fire during a Total Fire Ban is $39,652 or two years in jail or both, and on the spot fines of up to $496 can be issued for people breaching other campfire safety rules.

Campers have also been reminded to be COVID safe by wearing face masks, practising physical distancing, sanitising hands and keeping to group size limits.

urn:contentItem:5Y3H-NCN1-F0J6-J4DK-00000-00Student scholarships2020-01-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:52ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Student scholarships

Students who have been affected by bushfire and drought in Lithgow will have additional consideration given to them should they apply for a Government-funded scholarship to assist with the costs of their tertiary education.

Member for Calare, Andrew Gee said the Government wanted to ensure that drought and bushfire do not create additional barriers to high education for prospective students in the region.

"Especially those in the Mid- Western and Lithgow Council areas which have been badly affected by the recent bushfire crisis," Mr Gee said.

The Gospers Mountain bushfire is a record breaker - it is the world's largest forest fire from a single ignition point.

For 79 days it tore through bushland, destroying homes, shattering lives and killing countless wildlife.

"These scholarships will also help ease some of the financial burden at what has been a very difficult time for many," Mr Gee said.

Applications are now open for the fourth round of scholarships under the Australian Government's $58.1 million Rural and Regional Enterprise Scholarships program.

"A total of 19 tertiary students in the Calare electorate were awarded scholarships under round three of the program, so this is a great opportunity for more funding under the next round," Mr Gee said.

Eligible students commencing university or vocational education and training this year could benefit from up to $18,000 towards the cost of their studies.

"It's only fair that if you live in regional Australia, you get the same opportunities to access higher education as those living in metropolitan areas," Mr Gee said.

"There are more than 1000 scholarships available to students in regional and remote Australia including in Calare and I encourage everyone who needs financial support to gain a tertiary qualification or undertake further study to apply."

The scholarships also provide $500 for students undertaking an internship to ensure they are job-ready.

For more information or to apply, visit education.gov.au/rural-and-regional- enterprise-scholarships

urn:contentItem:62NH-T2D1-DY66-513N-00000-00Watch this for two hours of edge-of-the-seat tension2021-05-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisWatch this for two hours of edge-of-the-seat tension

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

STEPHEN ROMEI

Those Who Wish Me Dead (MA15+)In cinemas***½

We do not know the people who wish young Connor dead. We do know the people who will do anything to make that wish come true: two highly-disciplined, heavily-armed hit men named Jack and Patrick.

Played by Irish actor Aidan Gillen (Littlefinger in Game of Thrones) and English actor Nicholas Hoult, they dress like John Travolta and Samuel L. Jackson in Pulp Fiction and, like them, are stone cold killers.

When a woman stops her car on a remote road, thinking Jack (Gillen) needs help, he deals with her, and this is prior to the two agreeing that "From this point on we put down anyone who sees our faces".

Gillen and Hoult are brutally good in the opening sequences of this Montana-set survival thriller, which is directed and co-written by American actor and filmmaker Taylor Sheridan and based on the 2014 novel by American writer Michael Koryta, who is credited as lead screenwriter. The star, though, is 14-year-old Australian actor Finn Little, in his third feature film following the 2019 remake of Storm Boy and the 2020 Australian sci-fi thriller 2067.

He is Connor and he is on the run in the Montana wilderness because his forensic accountant father (Jake Webber) fled there from Florida following a "gas leak" explosion that killed a district attorney. He thinks he will be next to have an "accidental" death.

Whether he is right is for viewers to find out. For one reason or another, Connor is not with him as the assassins close in. He is with a forest firefighter named Hannah (Angelina Jolie), who takes him in when he approaches the one-person watch tower she is running. She is alone and has nightmares about what happened during a forest fire last summer.

Her former boyfriend, Ethan (Jon Bernthal), is the local sheriff. His wife Allison (an excellent Medina Senghore), who is six months pregnant, runs a survival school. If you have a feeling her fight or flee skills will become important, you may well be right.

The hit men, who are brothers in the novel, though this is not spelled out in the film, start a forest fire to keep the police and firefighters busy.

So this is where we are in Those Who Wish Me Dead: a troubled firefighter and a confused teen on the run from two ruthless killers as a fire builds around them. A sheriff and a survival expert in the wings. Off-camera, unknown to us, the powerful people who need the killing to be done.

The result is edge-of-the-seat tension for almost two hours. There is a character-setting sequence at the start that is a bit flabby - it tells us why Hannah is so messed up, and so daring as a result - but the rest is tight and controlled.

The performances lift the film, all round, but especially Little's scenes with Jolie. The young Australian actor does not let his American accent slip. "If you did the right thing, then why are you so scared," he asks his father, showing the innocence of youth.

Yet at the same time he has a dry teen humour that feels closer to the actor's real home. "No wonder you're so skinny," he tells Hannah when he samples the prepackaged food firefighters keep handy. She replies that she is "lean". It's a lovely bit of light in an otherwise bleak landscape.

Other exchanges between them bring some humour to the movie. You can almost think it's just a kid and a Hollywood star riffing in the bush, until the baddies show up. Jolie, as always, makes her character someone worth watching, for what she may or may not do.

This movie feels as though it has a thin premise, yet it works, thanks to the actors, the script (the director was Oscar nominated for writing the 2016 movie Hell or High Water) and perhaps above all the cinematography (Ben Richardson, who filmed the Oscar nominated 2012 hit Beasts of the Southern Wild).

The climactic sequence, when everyone, good or bad or in-between, meets the unbiased, indifferent, unstoppable fire, is superb.

-

Finding You (PG) In cinemas***½

If you are old enough to remember the Irish actor Patrick Bergin as Julia Roberts's husband from hell in the 1991 thriller Sleeping With The Enemy, or to recall him as Robin Hood that same year, you may feel a touch of nostalgia when he pops up in the romantic drama Finding You.

He is Seamus, long-time resident of a small coastal village in Ireland. He drinks too much, sleeps on a bench outside the bookstore and plays the fiddle in the only pub in town. He's not homeless but he may as well be. "What can you do?,'' says innkeeper Molly (Marion O'Dwyer). "It's his life."

That rhetorical question and its answer go to the interesting ideas explored in this movie, written and directed by American filmmaker Brian Baugh and based on Jenny B. Jones's 2011 young adult novel There You'll Find Me. As it is drawn from a YA novel there's a fair chance it's a coming of age story, and it is. Yet it reminds us that coming of age isn't restricted to teenagers.

The other older person central to the story is Cathleen Sweeney, played by the wonderful Vanessa Redgrave. She is living in a nursing home, has no family or friends and is "a crazy witch" (more on who says that soon).

Bergin, now 70, is still handsome, but he is not the heart-throb here. That role goes to one of the young leads, the Canadian actor with a name out of 1950s central casting: Jedidiah Goodacre.

He is Beckett Rush, star of a TV series with dragons that looks a lot like Game of Thrones. He starts to rethink his life when he meets Finley Sinclair (Rose Reid), a New York college student doing a semester in Ireland.

Finley, a violinist, is taking a break after failing an audition to the music school she is keen to be in. Beckett is shooting the latest series of his hit show in this remote village. They meet, have the standard We Have Nothing In Common banter and then fall for each other. There's an ebullient connection between the two young actors. They bounce off each other with a light, wry humour that is fun to watch.

The scenes where they rehearse Beckett's lines are terrific, and go to why he likes her. The scenes on location, with a manic European director, are amusing.

It is the growing mutual attraction between the violinist and the dragonslayer that sets up the main drama. Beckett, an actor since he was seven, is controlled by his father Montgomery (a subtly creepy Tom Everett Scott).

He is famous - his posters adorn every teen bedroom and he's mobbed when he walks in the street - but his public life, which includes headline grabbing stories invented by his father, is not his real life, or the life he wants. He would like to stop acting, in all senses of the word, and have a "normal" life, at least for a while. He sees Finley as the girl he can do that with.

His father, who has a multiple movie deal on the table, has a different view. He tells Finlay: "His love life is his career, so if you really care about him, don't get in the way."

The important link to this tangle of young would-be lovers involves Mrs Sweeney, who Finley has to befriend as part of the Irish studies part of her course. That "crazy witch" quote comes from her. In return, Mrs Sweeney's general view is, "If this is what young people have come to, then the whole world is doomed". Yet the world goes on, and history repeats.

Mrs Sweeney has her own sad secret story, one that also involves family and love, or the idea of love, and she has guarded it for decades.

Redgrave commands every scene she is in. The moment where, talking to Beckett, she mentions her own early attempts at acting, is fabulous.

This 115-minute movie has its smaltzy moments, but overall it is smartly entertaining. It is also a little thought-provoking. Time catches up with us all, so we should use it wisely while we have it. As one of the characters says, "In the end it's a choice".

urn:contentItem:60WY-MJ41-F0JP-W1MW-00000-00Fuel-load audits fail to deliver2020-09-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12Fuel-load audits fail to deliverBy PETER HUNT

THE Victorian Inspector General for Emergency Management's long-awaited inquiry into last summer's bushfire season has exposed failings in the state agencies' ability to measure their performance on curbing fuel loads.

"The effectiveness of Victoria's fuel management program cannot be compre-hensively measured due to a lack of measurable objectives adopted by all land and fire agencies, gaps in the current tools and models used, and a lack of capacity and capability to support the requirements of this work across the sector," IGEM Tony Pearce said.

The Weekly Times has previously reported on Forest Fire Management Victoria's shifting residual risk targets and refusal to release fuel load data and maps.

Mr Pearce recommended the Victorian Government develop a common set of objectives, metrics and reporting requirements for fuel management that form part of a compulsory regimen.

He said the reporting should: APPLY to all organisations with a legislated role in fuel management; across public and private land at all levels, state, regional and municipal.

INCLUDE residual risk where appropriate, but complementary metrics should be developed if residual risk cannot be determined.

Mr Pearce also found the calculation of residual risk was limited, "as the model used to calculate risk and risk reduction does not consider areas treated by mechanical means, roadsides and small parcels of land and is based on assumptions that consider housing assets only, the worst-case weather scenario and excludes multi-day events".

He said a significant portion of the community that fronted the inquiry were not satisfied with fuel management practices on public land.

"The rationale for this dissatisfaction and proposed alternative approaches are not easily reconciled due to fundamental differences in the values and experiences underpinning these beliefs," Mr Pearce said.

But he found that despite achieving the residual risk targets, there was a marked reduction in planned hectares treated.

In commenting on Victoria's ability to fight fires, the IGEM highlighted the invaluable role of loggers and timber contractors.

"The timber industry provides an important support capacity to fire management in Victorian forests with a skill set, knowledge base and operational experience in forest landscapes," Mr Pearce reported.

But he warned "the cessation of native forest harvesting by 2030 poses challenges for the fuel management program and bushfire response capacity across the state".

"Planning currently being undertaken by the Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning should be supported and continued to ensure the skills, knowledge and equipment of the industry remain accessible to land managers and fire agencies." urn:contentItem:5Y1C-FVK1-F0J6-J02N-00000-00Rain could help contain bushfires2020-01-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisRain could help contain bushfiresLucy Bladen

Heavy rainfall across south-eastern New South Wales has both helped and hindered crews, the Rural Fire Service said.

It comes as blazes burning in the South Coast and the Snowy Mountains could be contained this week.

The RFS has welcomed the rain but the downpours have prevented some backburning operations and some crews from fighting fires on the ground.

The Dunns Road fire which caused considerable damage in Batlow and Tumbarumba earlier this month has received about 25 millimetres of rainfall on Monday, NSW RFS public liaison officer Peter Jones.

"[Rainfall] has helped however as a result of the weather we've had to pull the crews out and they can't remain on the fire ground in these sorts of conditions as it's too slippery," he said.

While crews have been unable to work on the fireground on Monday, Mr Jones said he was confident enough had been done to contain the blaze, but this was not yet confirmed.

Activity also decreased on other fires burning west of the ACT, including the Mary's Hill and the Adaminaby Complex fires over the weekend, the ACT Emergency Services said.

At the NSW South Coast, the more than 300,000-hectare Currowan fire was labelled as "being controlled" on Monday.

NSW RFS operations officer Marc Donnelly said the ground had experienced "pretty big rainfall". The main area of focus for the fire was north-west of Kangaroo Valley. Mr Donnelly said he was confident, if current weather conditions persisted, the fire could be contained within the week.

The Clyde Mountain fire, on the southern flank of the Currowan blaze, is being controlled with the possibility of backburns postponed due to rainfall. The Charleys Forest fire, on the western flank of the Currowan blaze, is under control.

On the far South Coast, the Badja Forest Road fire is being controlled.

urn:contentItem:60FX-GR91-JCM0-633W-00000-00Peat fire clean-up in Sarsfield involves battling sunken, flooded paddocks2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisPeat fire clean-up in Sarsfield involves battling sunken, flooded paddocksBy Peter Somerville

More than six months after a patch of peat on Charlie Seehusen's Sarsfield farm caught fire, remediation works are still underway.

Peat, which is a precursor to coal, is prolific on the flats of Mr Seehusen's farm in East Gippsland, and it took many weeks to extinguish the fire.

Because peat fires burn underground, excavators were called in to help drain the flooded land.

Scars of the summer's bushfires are evident on Mr Seehusen's property, which is surrounded by charred bush.

Not the first time

This was not Mr Seehusen's first bushfire.

Forest Fire Management Victoria estimated more than 60 buildings and 4,000 stock were destroyed in fires that burned from February 21 to March 13 in 1965.

"I remember it quite clearly," Mr Seehusen said.

"The fires came through then, and back then there were seven houses, halls, the church got burned, the old bridge caught fire at Sarsfield over the Nicholson River.

"It was terrible because you were sitting there watching all these houses burn and we were only kids.I was nine but I still remember it very clearly.

"All these spot fires getting into houses and them burning up. It's not a good thing to see when you're a kid."

Peat remediation continues

Today, the scars from the bushfires at Sarsfield are clear.

The peat fire on Mr Seehusen's farm surrounded a major pipeline which carries gas to Sydney.

"The peat fire was very hot," he said.

"Down there in some parts it got to 800 degrees [Celsius], but most of it was 300-400 degrees, which is still damn hot.

"[The pipeline] can take 400 degrees, so naturally they were really concerned.

Extensive earthworks were carried out in attempt to dig trenches which could be flooded with water in a bid to extinguish the peat fire.

"When peat does burn, it'll sink. After a period of time, after the fire has gone through those hot spots can drop about a metre and you're left with big holes and a headache."

Mr Seehusen said remediating his paddocks had been a "real problem".

"We've had rain, so the holes are now all full of water and we've got to drain it out," he said.

"Then we'll have to get tonnes and tonnes of dirt and back fill it."

Mr Seehusen expected the remediation work could take more than a year.

urn:contentItem:61VC-XWC1-F0JP-W0H7-00000-00Prepare to bake2021-01-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Prepare to bakeIAN ROYALL

VICTORIA is bracing for a fiery blast with temperatures spiking up to the mid-40C mark in the state's north on Monday.

Melbourne is expected to reach 39C after what the weather bureau said would be an "oppressive night".

A total fire ban will be in place for six Victorian districts. Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp said Victorians should be prepared for the summer's worst day of high fire risk.

"This will be one of the most challenging 24 hours in relation to fires for our state," Mr Crisp said.

A cool change has been forecast to sweep across the state from the southwest after lunch and should reach Melbourne about 5pm, dropping temperatures by 10C to 15C within an hour.

Melburnians on Sunday tried to sleep during an uncomfortable night of temperatures in the high 20s.

The weather bureau took the unusual step of saying in its forecast that the night would be "oppressive".

Bureau meteorologist Michael Efron said the mercury would rise quickly on Monday morning, reaching the high 30s by noon.

CFA chief officer Jason Heffernan said conditions were expected to be the most dangerous this summer.

Winds of up to 60km/h could quickly propel any fires if they broke out. Fire bans are in place for the Mallee, Wimmera, North Country, North Central, East Gippsland and North East.

Forest Fire Management chief fire officer Chris Hardman said there was potential for "very significant and devastating" forest fires as conditions worsened.

"As we know, the prevailing northerly winds in Victoria tend to drive those fires in a long, narrow strip from north to south," he said.

"And when the risk really occurs is on the wind change, because a fire from that may only be say 500m wide (but) as soon as that change comes through it could be five, six, 10km long. And it is on that wind change where most of the devastating impacts occur." A total of 64 aircraft are on standby to help tackle fires.

Ambulance Victoria -director of emergency management Justin Dunlop said paramedics had been called to 24 incidents of people trapped in hot cars since Thursday. Two cases occurred on Sunday morning.

Zoo animals didn't let the heat ruffle their feathers, with ostriches at Werribee Zoo enjoying a dip in the lake.

Some of their neighbours turned to food for relief instead as camels and vervet monkeys went bananas for some frozen treats.

Over at Healesville, Tasmanian devils worked hard but their keepers worked harder, ensuring their furry friends were kept cool and comfortable as the mercury rose.

And at Melbourne Zoo swimming trunks were optional in the Asian elephant enclosure, where the residents spent the day splashing about in their pond.

urn:contentItem:60VK-49R1-F0J6-J1TN-00000-00Fire outlook facing catch-222020-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Fire outlook facing catch-22JAMIESON MURPHY AND CLAIRE HARRIS

Grassy areas to pose big threat in summer

WITHOUT good rainfall during spring, SA faces an elevated scrub and forest fire risk come summer.

But any rain that does come before summer will increase grass fuel loads, while the spring rainfall is often accompanied by thunderstorms than could see lightning igniting the dry parts of the state.

The catch-22 was revealed in the Bushfire and Natural Hazards Cooperative Research Centre's recently-released spring quarterly outlook report, which is used by fire authorities to make strategic decisions.

The report states that prolonged moisture deficits persist in SA, following the state's third driest June and July on record, with the rainfall outlook unlikely to overcome soil dryness and long-term rainfall deficiencies.

While wetter-than-average spring conditions are predicted in SA due to a La Nina alert, historically the weather pattern produces less rain for SA than the east coast.

A number of variables have to line up for these wetter conditions to occur in southern SA, including a negative Indian Ocean Dipole, but these signals are only likely to support wetter conditions for a brief period in early spring, rather than prolonged wetter conditions.

The fire danger season may start later than the previous two seasons, but any benefits from spring rain will quickly be marginalised once warmer weather occurs, according to BNHCRC chief executive officer Richard Thornton.

"In the spring in years when we get above-average rainfall, we see large-scale development of grass areas, particularly in cropping and grassland areas. Once it starts to warm up in the summer period, we may see an increased fire risk at that point," he said.

Without downplaying the risk of fires in forestry areas, Dr Thornton said grassfires would likely be the biggest threat this season in SA.

"Forest fires, like what we saw on Kangaroo Island at the start of this year, are the big ferocious fires that tower high into the air, but we know from experience that while grassfires may not be as dramatic, they are just as deadly," he said.

"We have seen many instances in the past in SA where grassfires have claimed lives, infrastructure and properties.

"They start easily, they're fast-moving, they can change direction very quickly with wind, and have a chance of catching people out."

Western SA, including much of the Eyre Peninsula, the Flinders Ranges and the Riverland, are still experiencing drought-like conditions, which is likely to limit grass and crop growth.

These regions will be monitored closely, especially in areas of native vegetation and scrub, which could present challenges as the bushfire season progresses.

urn:contentItem:5Y03-J571-JD3N-51SJ-00000-00Tinder-dry park fire fears2020-01-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Tinder-dry park fire fearsGEORGIA HOLLOWAY

OCEAN Grove residents fear a fire at a prominent nature reserve could wreak havoc for the growing township.

Long grass and dead tree debris littering the Ocean Grove Nature Reserve have sparked outrage at the dangers a fire would pose for nearby built-up housing and shopping developments directly across from the reserve on Grubb Rd.

"It would be impossible to stop a fire there if it got going," said Geoff Stevens, 77, who has lived south of the reserve for 37 years.

"All it will take is a very hot northerly wind and the fire will go straight to the beach and wipe out the town." In 1997, fire tore through the reserve, putting the Woodlands Estate under threat.

Two additional estates have since popped up bordering the reserve, adding to the risk for fire disaster.

The reserve, containing one of the last remaining woodlands on the Bellarine Peninsula, has attracted people and native animals since it opened to the public in 1971. But its current condition alarms residents.

Mr Stevens is among a growing group of locals demanding action. "Twenty-five to 30 years ago, the CFA did a cold burn every winter and we felt safe," he said. "It is terrible for it not to be cleared." But Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said appropriate risk management had been taken.

He said annual slashing and track clearing at the reserve took place early last month, with additional work brought forward during the next 10 days of milder conditions.

"We are prepared to undertake planned burns when it is safe to do so," he said. "Our No. 1 priority is to protect life and property.

"Not all forests are the same and not all years are the same."When conditions allow for safe, controlled burning and fuel reduction, we will undertake planned burning programs over larger areas."

urn:contentItem:61SJ-5RV1-JD34-V2DM-00000-00Fire risk reigns despite a damp start to the summer2021-01-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 12Fire risk reigns despite a damp start to the summerMike Foley Climate and energy correspondent

NSW and Victoria still face increasing bushfire risks this summer due to the growing likelihood of severe grass fires, despite recent wet weather and the vast amount of fuel burnt out by the Black Summer blazes a year ago.

Above-average rainfall has brought a welcome flush of green, watered the parched soil and replenished grass on the rangelands and pastures from northern Victoria, the Riverina and right across NSW, which had been stripped bare by years of drought.

But the east coast is not out of the woods, and with so much grass and fuel across the country, a run of hot days would bring extreme fire danger warnings. "As we've seen in the past couple of weeks, it doesn't take many days in a row of hot temperatures to get grass fires running," Bushfire and Natural Hazards Co-operative Research Centre chief executive Richard Thornton said.

"The grass will brown off, which makes them available to burn as we've seen in South Australia, Western Australia and Melbourne recently. I'm sure we'll see total fire bans across most jurisdictions this year."

Australian National University Climate Change Institute professor Mark Howden said hot, dry, low humidity and windy conditions that fan grass fires should be expected in coming weeks and months.

"Periods of weather which provide high fire risk are normal and likely in any season, even when the rainfall is above average," Professor Howden said.

NSW Rural Fire Service spokesman Greg Allan said the return of pasture growth has been welcome, but it's also meant grass fires are now "our major focus for the summer".

One factor behind the high volume of grass in NSW is that livestock numbers are at their lowest in decades after years of drought. "While many people may have seen a bushfire before, grass fires can burn three times faster and become quite dangerous," he said.

The fire agencies urged people to refresh their bushfire emergency plans, including downloading the emergency warning smartphone apps from the Victorian Country Fire Authority, or the NSW RFS Fires Near Me.

CFA deputy chief officer (bushfire) Alen Slijepcevic expects an "average fire season" in Victoria, which would nevertheless include significant fire risks. "In Victoria people expect the summer to bring grass fires and even in a normal year we can have a significant one," Mr Slijepcevic said.

Last week, residents of Taylors Lakes in Melbourne's north-west evacuated their residences as a grass fire, spurred by hot weather, swept towards them before being brought under control without property loss.

However, Victorian farmers have been busy reducing fuels and potential grass-fire risks after reaping a bumper grain harvest in Victoria's cropping districts, and cutting pastures to replenish depleted hay stores.

urn:contentItem:5XXS-26M1-DXX7-H1DK-00000-00Victorian bushfires official death toll rises to three as authorities confirm car accident was fire-related2020-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisVictorian bushfires official death toll rises to three as authorities confirm car accident was fire-related

The official death toll in Victoria's bushfire crisis has risen to three, authorities have confirmed.

Forest Fire Management Victoria staff member Matt Kavanagh, 43, died in a car accident last Friday.

An investigation has concluded it was because of fires.

Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville said Mr Kavanagh and his colleague were involved in a two-vehicle crash on the Goulburn Valley Highway.

"Tragically, the 43-year-old couldn't be revived and died at the scene," she said.

Mr Kavanagh is survived by his wife and two children.

"This news has come as a huge shock," Ms Neville said.

"He's been remembered for his friendly and welcoming nature, his passion for the environment and nature and his love of fly-fishing."

Mr Kavanagh's colleague was taken to hospital in a stable condition after the crash.

Buchan "hero" Mick Roberts was identified as the first victim of the bushfire emergency, while Maramingo Creek timber worker Fred Becker was confirmed dead at the weekend.

Hundreds of homes have been destroyed as the fires rage across East Gippsland and the state's north-east.

Fire crews are today attempting controlled burns near coastal communities in a bid to protect property ahead of a wind change predicted to cause problems across fire grounds later this week.

Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp said fire conditions on Friday were likely to rise to extreme in the Northern Country, severe in the Mallee and north-east and very high in East Gippsland.

Rain and cooler temperatures this week have granted a brief reprieve to firefighters, but Ms Neville said the rain had "in no way changed the risk".

"These fires remain dangerous, dynamic and volatile," she said.

Another expected round of dry lighting, combined with a forecast wind change, could potentially cause fast-moving fires across Victoria, she said.

More to come.

urn:contentItem:5Y03-YWY1-DYG0-92BV-00000-00FED:Ski resorts use snowguns in fire fight2020-01-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSFED:Ski resorts use snowguns in fire fightSYDNEY Jan 10

  Snowmaking machines are being used to help battle fires in the alpine region with a wind change potentially placing ski resorts under threat.
   NSW's Thredbo Resort, which is among the many ski fields closed until further notice due to the fires, has been running its snowmaking machines non-stop for days to wet the ground, Aneeki Ski Lodge owner Stephen Turner said.


   "It stops the ember attack," he told AAP on Friday.
   "At 1800m, we're above the treeline so ... we can protect the ski assets."
   The potential for disaster is clear after buildings at Selwyn Snow Resort were severely damaged when the Dunns Road fire hit the Kosciuszko National Park ski destination last weekend.
   Mr Turner said he was most concerned about a southerly wind change, recorded at 90 kilometres at Albury, that could fan a 3600-hectare blaze south of Thredbo.
   Embers could particularly affect the golf course and elevated lodges, he said.
   "It'll be like a blowtorch," he said.
   "If it gets into the ski resort ... It can burn around the village and keep going.
   "There's no point having a ski resort with no lifts, lodges or other infrastructure."
   Aircraft was used to dump fire retardant on a fire near Charlotte Pass on Friday.
   Snowmaking lines were also primed and crews on stand-by on Victoria's Mount Buller, the mountain's resort management said on Friday.
   "The main risk for the remainder of Friday and Saturday is dry lightning strikes as the weather change starts to move through the resorts from around 5pm," chief executive Mark Bennetts said in a statement.
   Forest Fire Management Victoria said they had more than 200 firefighters and a dozen aircraft operating across the Buffalo Valley.
   FFMV Ovens region deputy incident controller Jarrod Hayse told reporters most of the 180km of fire perimeter was uncontained and significant impact was expected on plantations and alpine areas.

urn:contentItem:61SS-7871-F0J6-J2W0-00000-00Bushfire risk rises despite wet summer2021-01-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 17Bushfire risk rises despite wet summerMike Foley Climate and energy correspondent

Victoria and NSW are still facing increasing bushfire risks this summer due to the growing likelihood of severe grass fires, despite recent wet weather and the vast amount of fuel burnt out by the Black Summer blazes a year ago.

Above-average rainfall has brought a welcome flush of green, watered the parched soil and replenished grass on the rangelands and pastures from northern Victoria, the Riverina and right across NSW, which had been stripped bare by years of drought.

But the east coast is not out of the woods, and with so much grass and fuel, a run of several hot days will still bring extreme fire danger warnings.

"As we've seen in the past couple of weeks, it doesn't take many days in a row of hot temperatures to get grass fires running," Bushfire and Natural Hazards Co-operative Research Centre chief executive Richard Thornton said.

"The grass will brown off, which makes them available to burn, as we've seen in South Australia, Western Australia and Melbourne recently. I'm sure we'll see total fire bans across most jurisdictions this year."

Australian National University Climate Change Institute professor Mark Howden said hot, dry, low humidity and windy conditions which fan grass fires should be expected in coming weeks and months.

"Periods of weather which provide high fire risk are normal and likely in any season even when the rainfall is above average," Professor Howden said.

NSW Rural Fire Service spokesman Greg Allan said the return of pasture growth has been welcome, but it's also meant grass fires are now "our major focus for the summer". One factor behind the high volume of grass in NSW is that livestock numbers are at their lowest numbers in decades after years of drought.

"While many people may have seen a bushfire before, grass fires can burn three times faster and become quite dangerous," Mr Allan said.

The fire agencies urged people to refresh their bushfire emergency plans, including downloading the emergency warning smartphone apps from the Victorian Country Fire Authority, or the NSW RFS Fires Near Me.

"Grass fires are not as intense as a raging forest fire, but they can be lethal," Dr Thornton said.

"They throw embers ahead of the fire and can cause properties to burn too."

CFA deputy chief officer bushfire, Alen Slijepcevic, expects an "average fire season" in Victoria, which would nevertheless include significant fire risks.

"In Victoria people expect the summer to bring grass fires and even in a normal year we can have a significant one," Mr Slijepcevic said.

Last week residents of Taylors Lakes in Melbourne's north-west evacuated their residences as a grass fire, spurred by hot weather, swept towards them before being brought under control without property loss.

However, Victorian farmers have been busy reducing fuels and potential grass fire risks, after reaping a bumper grain harvest in Victoria's cropping districts, and cutting pastures to replenish depleted hay stores.

"In saying that, this is one of the most bushfire-prone areas in the world and there is no room for complacency. People need to know their emergency plans, and maintain clearance [of fuel] around their house," Mr Slijepcevic said.

urn:contentItem:5XXY-MSF1-DYG0-94FB-00000-00TALENT ALERT: 2019 OUR HOTTEST AND DRIEST YEAR ON RECORD: BOM CLIMATE SUMMARY AUSTRALIA has just experienced not only its hottest, but also its driest year on record, which has contributed to the devastating bushfire conditions much of the country is now facing.2020-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisTALENT ALERT: 2019 OUR HOTTEST AND DRIEST YEAR ON RECORD: BOM CLIMATE SUMMARY AUSTRALIA has just experienced not only its hottest, but also its driest year on record, which has contributed to the devastating bushfire conditions much of the country is now facing.



   The Bureau of Meteorology's 2019 Annual Climate Statement released today also confirmed that the national annual accumulated Forest Fire Danger Index was the highest it's been since records began.



   These extreme and dangerous conditions are Australia's new normal under climate change.

   We are in the midst of a bushfire crisis, much of the country is still suffering through drought and an estimated 50 percent of corals on the Great Barrier Reef have died due to bleaching caused by rising ocean temperatures. Now more than ever, we need to act on climate change and reduce our emissions to protect Australia, our wildlife, our natural systems, and future generations.

urn:contentItem:5XX0-DMR1-F0J6-J23W-00000-0032,700 properties lose power indefinitely again in Bay, Moruya2020-01-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:52ZLexisNexis32,700 properties lose power indefinitely again in Bay, Moruya

Essential Energy bushfire update - Saturday, 4 January

8pm: Essential Energy advises that unfortunately 32,711 customers in the Batemans Bay and Moruya region have lost power again at around 7pm this evening, and is advising customers that power will not be restored overnight as safe access is not available into the damaged area. An estimated time for when power will be restored to these customers will be available once we can gain safe access to the network . We thank the community for their understanding in this unpredictable and difficult time.

Essential Energy bushfire update - Saturday, 4 January.

5.52pm: Power has been restored to 20,000 properties in Bay, Moruya.

"Essential Energy crews have been able to restore power progressively to more than 20,000 customers.30,627 customers in the Batemans Bay and Moruya region lost power at 3pm this afternoon due to bushfires affecting infrastructure. Essential Energey said 9,500 customers remain without power," the service says.

"An estimated time for when power will be restored to these customers will not be available until we can gain safe access to the network," a spokesperson said.

"We are continuing to work closely with the RFS however don't expect access to be available until Monday."

3.22pm: Essential Energy says 30,627 customers in the Batemans Bay and Moruya region have just lost power due to bushfire affecting infrastructure.

"We will work in close consultation with the Rural Fire Service to ensure our crews can safely access the area, then we will be able to give an estimated time to restore the power," a spokeswoman said.

"Further outages may occur as the fires continue through the south-east area."

The Clyde Mountain Fire and Badja Forest Fire are converging under firstly strong northerly winds, with a southerly change due late this afternoon.

More details as they come to hand.

urn:contentItem:61DS-V5J1-F0J6-J0G6-00000-00UPDATE: Bush fire at Monarto South2020-12-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisUPDATE: Bush fire at Monarto South

3pm update The Country Fire Service (CFS) reported that the threat from the Brinkley fire had reduced, however people were reminded to take care in the area.

Smoke will reduce visibility on the roads and there is a risk of trees and branches falling.

-Details: For information on bushfires check the CFS website www.cfs.sa.gov.au or phone the Bushfire Information Hotline on 1800 362 361.

This message at the time of sending is the final message in relation to this event. This message expires at: 01/12/2020 15:45

1.30pm There is a Bushfire Watch and Act Message issued for Brinkley, for the Monarto South, Ferries McDonald Road fire enacted at 1.21pm. The uncontrolled forest fire is burning in an easterly direction towards Brinkley and Ferries McDonald Conservation Park.

People located in the area are asked to take action now as the bushfire may threaten their safety.

If people are not prepared, they must leave now and if the path is clear, go to a safer place. Do not enter this area as conditions are dangerous.

Homes that have been built to withstand a bushfire, and are prepared to the highest level, may provide safety.

You may lose power, water, phone and data connections.

Fire crews are responding but you should not expect a firefighter at your door.

For updates listen to your local ABC radio station on a battery powered radio, visit the CFS website www.cfs.sa.gov.au or phone the Bushfire Information Hotline on 1800 362 361.

WHAT TO DO:

Check and follow your Bushfire Survival Plan. Protect yourself from the fire's heat, put on protective clothing. Tell family and friends of your plans. IF YOU ARE LEAVING:

Leave now, don't delay. Roads may become blocked or access may change. Smoke will reduce visibility. Secure your pets for travel. If you become stuck in your car, park away from bushes, cover yourself, get onto the floor as the windows may break from the intense heat. PREPARE TO DEFEND:

Identify a spot to shelter in, with more than one exit, keep moving away from the heat of the fire. Bring pets inside and restrain them. Move flammable materials such as doormats, wheelie bins and outdoor furniture away from your house. KEEP UP TO DATE:

CFS website : cfs.sa.gov.au Bushfire Information Hotline 1800 362 361 For hearing or speech impaired users, phone 1300 555 727 then ask for 1800 362 361 For teletype service TTY 133 677 CFS on Facebook or Twitter On local ABC radio, FIVEaa, or one of our other Emergency Broadcast Partners. Do not rely on a single source for warning information.

For emergencies call Triple Zero (000)

******

1.10pm

At about 12.52pm today, Tuesday, December 1, Country Fire Service units have been called out to a grass fire at a property on Ferries McDonald Road, at Monarto South.

It is reported that the fire was started by the use of an angle grinder and is heading towards the conservation park.

Callouts have been made to the Murray Bridge, Monarto, Callington and Strathalbyn CFS units to attend.

urn:contentItem:634N-4R41-JD3N-50X8-00000-00National park status will benefit forests2021-07-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 17National park status will benefit forests

NEW national parks in Victoria's central west don't dodge the challenge of managing forests, they help to answer it ("Park status no panacea," WT, July 7).

Though park funding right across Victoria should sensibly be doubled, new national and regional parks like Wombat, Mt Cole, the Pyrenees and Wellsford will nevertheless have access to more management resources and expertise than they had as state forests.

Threatened animal and plant species will get attention, and visitor facilities and access should improve.

These areas are worth more protected for nature conservation and recreation then they are when logged and exploited.

And parks don't increase fire risk, that risk is managed by Forest Fire Management Victoria across all public land tenures and increasingly on private land as well.

The use of mechanical thinning in Australian forest types has been shown again and again not to decrease the risk of fire, but could in fact make fire conditions worse while also damaging habitat for threatened wildlife.

These much-needed additions to Victoria's park estate will ensure they get the care and management they deserve while also making them more accessible to the general public.

Jordan Crook, Victorian National Parks Association nature campaigner

Activists need an education IF MR Meddick thinks his animal activist comrades should be pardoned for their poultry pantomime ("Activists fall for decoys," WT Jul 7), perhaps they should go on an excursion to a nearby wetlands run by Field and Game.

There they can be taught what a duck actually looks like, under the many terrific educational programs that Field and Game operate, alongside their estimable conservation efforts.

If these avian enthusiasts weren't so blinded by ideology, they might have their ducks in a row and not have ended up as the boy who cried wildfowl.

Mr Meddick calling the Game Management Authority "corrupt" and "disgraceful" seems excessive for fining these lettuce-lovers, given that possession of birds without a licence is a complete breach of the law.

Beverley McArthur MP, Member for Western Victoria

Come and see how shooters behave I WOULD argue most strongly duck shooters cause far greater damage than a couple of animal activists who "supposedly" thought some 50 duck decoys were ducks that duck shooters had exceeded their bag numbers by.

The author, Peter Hunt, fails to see the far worse cruelty and treatment of gentle native bird species by shooters than a misguided article about "two animal activists who attempted to dob in duck hunters for too many birds". I found this particularly insulting when the author stated: " ... after they failed to understand that not everything that looks like a duck quacks like one." I would like to invite Peter Hunt to a duck shooting season. I would like him to see first hand duck shooters encouraging their clearly untrained dogs, ripping birds apart while still alive. He can witness duck shooters slowly strangling birds then see the poor birds writhing, struggling and kicking on shooters' belts. He can see ducks left unretrieved by shooters suffering unimaginable pain, and the shells, beer bottles and unburied human waste left behind year after year. He can see the damage caused to sacred Aboriginal sites such as middens, crushed and scattered, trees cut for firewood that are hundreds of years old, and the ongoing contempt and destruction of wetland habitats by these neanderthal red necked Philistines.

Compared to the two animal activists who supposedly mistook 50 decoys as real ducks l know whose side l am on. Not all of us who live in the bush agree with your unfunny comments, Mr Hunt.

Kate Bossence, Kerang

Who does NFF really support?

IN declaring the Foreign Investment Review Board's latest fees to apply to purchase our land as "exorbitant", National Farmers' Federation vice-president David Jochinke leaves us in no doubt that his organisation continues to support the powerful and cashed up foreign entities and the unabated sale of our farms to them ("Foreign buyers slugged," WT, July 7).

Australians wishing to buy farms of their own but who are shut out of the market must be left wondering why the NFF, which purports to represent Australian farmers, would put the interests of overseas investors before those of their fellow countrymen and women.

Jock Munro, Rankin's Springs NSW

urn:contentItem:60R5-5T81-JD34-V1XW-00000-00State may face reduced fire season risk2020-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8State may face reduced fire season riskBenjamin Preiss and Peter Hannam

Victoria faces a reduced threat of another horrific bushfire season this summer with wetter than average conditions expected in coming months.

But emergency services have warned against complacency, saying the threat of grass fires, crop fires and floods still looms large.

Many Victorian communities are still reeling from the summer's catastrophic fires.

Conditions in the Indian and Pacific oceans are aligning to lift the odds that damper than normal weather will continue for the eastern two-thirds of Australia for most of the rest of 2020.

The warming of the ocean off Western Australia's north is likely to favour the flow of increased moisture across the continent.

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said grass and crop fires would take "centre stage" in the early part of the fire season. Mr Hardman said one-day bushfires were also possible and residents of fire-prone areas should have their plans in place.

Planned burns were being done throughout the year, including this week in the Wimmera.

"Whenever that opportunity to burn window opens we'll be there doing it."

State Emergency Service chief officer Tim Wiebusch said Victorian catchments were already wet, which raised the prospect of floods. "With the potential of the La Nina this spring there's a real risk of above average rainfall and that could lead to flash flooding across our urban areas but also riverine flooding across regional Victoria."

Warmer than usual conditions in the western equatorial Pacific have lifted the chance of a La Nina later this year to 70 per cent, three times the usual likelihood.

In La Nina years, high-pressure systems typically set up in the Tasman and further south than usual, directing moisture-laden tropical air over eastern Australia.

Such years also elevated the likelihood of more tropical lows and cyclones forming in northern Australia, Dr Watkins said.

The first coast-crossing cyclone is about three weeks earlier than in a usual year, raising the possibility of flooding such as was seen between 2010 and 2012. A year ago, the climate influences leaned the other way, intensifying a drought across much of eastern Australia and setting up record-breaking forest fires.

This year, the bushfire risk has been moderated although the good rains will also boost the threat of grass fires if there are short, dry spells that leave an increased fuel load.

Locked down Melburnians pining to get away for the piste of the Alps might be cheered to know that the snow season has generally been poor.

Although there was an outbreak of Antarctic cold late in August.

urn:contentItem:60NT-WCK1-DY19-C0GK-00000-00'Nothing short of catastrophic': Man whose driving caused firefighter's death jailed2020-08-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexis'Nothing short of catastrophic': Man whose driving caused firefighter's death jailedDavid Estcourt

A man whose driving caused the death of firefighter Mathew Kavanagh during last summer's horror bushfire season has been sentenced to two years and three months' jail.

A man whose dangerous driving caused the death of a firefighter during last summer's horror bushfire season has been jailed.

Novak John Selby, 47, will spend a maximum of two years and three months in prison after pleading guilty to dangerous driving that caused the death in January of Mathew Kavanagh, 43, on the Goulburn Valley Highway at Thornton, north-east of Melbourne.

Mr Kavanagh, a Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighter, was a passenger in a utility vehicle being driven by John Martyn, who survived.

On Tuesday County Court judge Gavan Meredith reminded Selby that he had initially denied responsibility for the crash.

"In response to Mr Martyn having told a police officer that your vehicle was on the wrong side of the road, you responded, ???No, you were on the wrong side of the road,' " Judge Meredith said.

"Your actions at the scene of the accident in seeking to blame ... the other driver do not reflect well on you, nor does your indication to police that you would not present yourself at the final hearing of this matter."

The judge said the consequences of Selby's offending were "nothing short of catastrophic".

The court heardSelby had written a letter of apology to the victim's family.

Mr Kavanagh died after the passenger side of the truck he was in was struck by Selby's Toyota Land Cruiser. After the crash, Selby briefly lost consciousness before struggling out of his vehicle. He spent three days in hospital.

In a police interview following his release from hospital, he said that immediately after the crash he ran over to the other vehicle and asked the driver, "What were you doing? You were in my lane."

He later accepted that he caused the crash.

Prosecutors conceded there was evidence that suggested the dangerous driving was a result of momentary inattention, and that there was no evidence of speeding, using a mobile phone or other poor driving prior to the crash.

"Your attention was elsewhere for such a period of time that whilst negotiating a bend in the road, you crossed completely into the oncoming lane," Judge Meredith said.

Selby has served 232 days of pre-sentence detention. He will be eligible for parole in 15 months and had ben disqualified from obtaining a driver's licence for 20 months.

He was also fined $500 for having trace amounts of cannabis in his system before the crash. The prosecution conceded the trace amounts did not effect his driving ability.

urn:contentItem:6335-8BV1-JD3N-51SR-00000-00Despite risks, not a cent for enforcement2021-07-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 19Despite risks, not a cent for enforcement

I FIND it ironic that while the Andrews Government prepares to allow camping on licenced river frontages later this year, at the same time, Goulburn-Murray Water and Forest Fire Management Victoria are publicly reminding people not to camp illegally around Lake Eildon.

Illegal camping has been an issue for some time. Authorised officers only want people to camp in designated areas to control and prevent risks that campers can cause to the environment through water pollution, littering, invading private property and leaving fires burning.

The risks authorised officers are preventing is what river frontage licence holders may have to soon face. While the risks and concerns are well known, the state Labor Government has not delivered a single cent in their budget to boost enforcement in the area once their legislation goes through.

Cindy McLeish, Member for Eildon Power workers just drive through I WHOLLY agree with your article "Rent for lines on land" (WT, July 30). I too have 66kV and 22kV transmission lines running through our property as well as a new control cable recently installed for the wind generators installed in the Seymour area. This cable runs a lot lower and is unsightly. We were never consulted, just told about the works.

We have three lots of contractors coming on to the property checking the lines every few months, which always annoys us, as well as the gate being left open or the padlock not locked.

We haven't been able to erect buildings where we wanted to, due to the egress. I think too, it's only fair that we are compensated either by a rates concession or rent.

Mark Davies Enough global warming alarmism LIKE most farmers I habitually sit down at lunch on a Wednesday to scroll through my "farmers' paper" The Weekly Times as I have done the last 40 years.

As I sit down I think about the coolest summer in many years and the snow on Christmas Day and the two longest snow seasons in Australia the last two years and record rainfall in NSW. I think about the record crop production last year, farming land doubling in price, and the coldest May in the US this year for 145 years.

But nearly every second page in The Weekly Times is telling us of the impending doom of global warming where rain and snow will never be seen again and the demise of agriculture if we don't eliminate fossil fuels. This propaganda is making me angry.

CO2 is a miracle gas essential to life and to grow food, and the uptrend in the last 30 years of world food production proves this. Once our mining industry is gone they will come for the ag sector. No one denies climate change, but if climate change is a front for global warming alarmism then I reject it as an outright lie.

Simon Grigg, Patchewollock Vale paint maker David Haymes DAVID Haymes made a magnificent contribution to both his local community and to Australian manufacturing. His recent passing is a sad loss for his wife Jenny, his family and the Australian community.

He was appointed managing director of Haymes Paint - the company founded by his father, Henry in 1935 - before he was 30. When David was chief executive during 1974 to 2008, Haymes Paint grew to become Australia's largest family-owned paint company.

David, an astute businessman, became a household name through the television ads depicting "paint flowing through his veins".

He was a strong advocate for domestic manufacturing and was a leader in the Australian paint industry.

He loved Ballarat and did all he could to advance the community. He was a member of many local organisations and mentor to others.

Phil Roberts, Author, Haymes: Paint Flowing Through The Veins Thank activists for nothing IT MUST be hard for vigilante activists to address the reality that wild ducks are an edible and renewable natural resource that is harvested in a lawful and sustainable manner.

The letter ("GMA out to catch the wrong people," June 23) trying to gloss over law-breaking protesters with the euphemism of "volunteers" fails to recognise these people have no positive impact on wildlife populations. The proportion of ducks harvested by hunting is only a segment of natural population dynamics; gains in good seasons, losses in drought as well as natural predation by raptors, snakes etc. Protesters have saved nothing, nature strikes its own balances.

Hans Witteveen, Seymour

urn:contentItem:5Y98-YS21-F0J6-J2ND-00000-00Planned burn for Little Desert National Park on Thursday and Friday2020-02-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisPlanned burn for Little Desert National Park on Thursday and FridayEliza Berlage

Residents and motorists in West Wimmera may encounter smoke and low visibility on roads due to a planned burn in Little Desert National Park on Thursday and Friday.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Wimmera District Manager Wimmera Glenn Rudolph issued a notice on Tuesday about a 300 hectare fuel reduction burn to take place in the central block north break west.

He said the objective of the burn was to provide bushfire protection by reducing overall fuel hazard and bushfire hazard in the landscape and FFMV said it should be completed between the hours of noon and 6pm on Thursday and Friday, weather and fuel moisture conditions permitting.

Advice Smoke

If you are experiencing any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure, the Department of Health and Human Services advises that you should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024

Close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering

Roads

urn:contentItem:5Y9G-XW91-F0J6-J1VD-00000-00Experts say it's business as usual2020-02-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 8Experts say it's business as usualPeter Kennedy

EDITORIAL

THE threat of fire is never far from the minds of people who live in our region, and for those of us in Bendigo - a self-professed city in the forest, the concern will always be there.

The forests that surround much of our city were here long before we built thousands of homes right up the interface, and consequently, the onus is on us to find ways to live with the threat while still enjoying the benefits of living so close to the bush.

Complacency is something none of us can afford to allow to sink in, and the beauty that exists in the forests that ring our city also represent the very thing we fear most.

Understanding how fire management works is important, and the advice of experts needs to be heeded, lest hysteria overcome us all.

The business as usual approach announced this week by Forest Fire Management makes sense, and recent history is littered with examples where strategic burns conducted during the cooler months of the year have fortunately turned out to be a major contributing factor to essential assets and possibly lives being saved in a subsequent bushfire.

It must also be said, our fire season is far from over, and we should continue to be wary of the potential for fires and the dangers they might bring.

And while some experts have stated the most recent bushfire crisis can be attributed to a lack of planned burns, the list of other potential contributors is a long one, and we're kidding ourselves to think it could all be so simple.

This week's announcement of a planned burns schedule that includes more operations than were held last year across our region comes as the Bureau of Meteorology releases its latest weather outlook for autumn.

Warmer overnight temperatures are expected, but there's no strong indicator of how warm daytime temperatures might be.

Rainfall could be above the average for the western half of the state, but again, there's no strong indicator for the rest of us, although rainfall throughout March is expected to be above average for most parts of Victoria.

urn:contentItem:5Y8W-1931-F0J6-J0XF-00000-00Firefighters save koala areas2020-02-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:16:51ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Firefighters save koala areasAlasdair McDonald

While images of burned koalas graced headlines across the world due to the unprecedented bushfire emergency, it seems one, while small, population managed to avoid the devastation.

A mother, with a possible burn injury on one paw and glaucoma, and her joey spent 12 days alone in a stringybark tree on a private property in the Murrah forest, before leaving the tree over recent days - creating optimism in researchers the pair will remain healthy.

"Very little of the area being used by koalas has been burnt," the state government's local Koala Recovery Coordinator Chris Allen said.

"On the whole it was only moderate, and not extremely severe fire that passed through."

He said firefighters worked hard to prevent the Badja Forest fire from entering sensitive areas of the Murrah Flora Reserve and Biamanga National Park. Mr Allen said it is unknown why the mother had taken refuge in the tree for so long, and the marsupials may establish a home range nearby, or look further afield. He said samples of her faeces have been sent to Sydney University to test for chlamydia and koala retrovirus.

"She is feeding well, browsing and suckling her young, who is beginning to eat leaves in the tree, and eating supplementary food from branches left under the tree," Mr Allen said.

He said recently captured video of the pair indicates the joey is likely around 14-months-old, and two months beyond the usual age for weening off its mother's milk. Mr Allen said it is unknown why the local population, which sits at 50 individuals spanning 25,000 hectares, has remained relatively unchanged. He said it could be an "underestimate" and there hasn't been "any evidence of a shift in the numbers" since 2009.

The state government is currently holding an inquiry into koala populations and habitats, which last week heard from representatives protecting the vulnerable animal's populations throughout the bushfires. World Wide Fund for Nature conservation scientist Dr Stuart Blanch told the inquiry as many as 10,000 koalas, or a third of the total NSW population, may have been lost to drought and bushfires.
